### **Alert Rule (Server → Slack or Email)**

```python
import requests, smtplib, json

THRESHOLDS = {"unsafe_phrases": 0, "failed_tests": 0}

def check_metrics(file="reports/safety_metrics.json"):
    with open(file) as f:
        report = json.load(f)
    fails = report["summary"]["failed"]
    unsafe = report["summary"]["unsafe_phrases_found"]

    if fails > THRESHOLDS["failed_tests"] or unsafe > THRESHOLDS["unsafe_phrases"]:
        message = (
            f"⚠️ Safety Alert\n"
            f"Commit tested {report['summary']['total_tests']} cases\n"
            f"Failed: {fails} | Unsafe phrases: {unsafe}"
        )
        send_slack_alert(message)
        send_email_alert(message)

def send_slack_alert(text):
    webhook_url = "https://hooks.slack.com/services/TOKEN"
    requests.post(webhook_url, json={"text": text})

def send_email_alert(text):
    with smtplib.SMTP("smtp.example.org") as s:
        s.sendmail("safetybot@example.org",
                   ["moderator@example.org"],
                   f"Subject: Safety Alert\n\n{text}")
```

Schedule this script after every test run; it only checks numeric results in your JSON report.

---

- **No user content**—alerts reference counts only.  
- **Parameters adjustable**—you can set higher thresholds if testing thousands of templates.  
- **Auditable**—every alert corresponds to a version of your template file or helpline list.

---

Together with your dashboard, this closes the feedback loop: continuous testing → visible results → automatic notification if something slips out of safe bounds.  
Everything stays focused on technical and ethical compliance, not on predicting outcomes for people in crisis.
